columns.text: In this task, **we will determine the bond real and nominal return what the difference between them.**

**a)**

Changing the percentage in the number of currencies an investor has is a **nominal** return rate. **This return does not contain a percent of inflation**.

Changing in the buying condition, how much you can pay with your currencies is the **real** return rate. **This return does contain a percent of inflation.**

**The future investors give more attention to the real returns.** The reason is that the real returns will provide clear expectations of how much the investor will earn. 

Nominal returns are higher and do not contain inflation. So, the investor will predict a higher return against reality.

b)

**The Fisher effect tells us the correlation between the nominal return, real return, and rising prices(inflation)**. Investors are always willing to invest in a security with a positive actual return. The only way for the investor to invest in the negative return of a bond will be in the time of deflation. The reason is that holding a large amount of cash is difficult to controlled and the investors are willing to have a negative return (slightly below zero).

If we write down the formula for the Fisher effect will be easier to understand the relationship between those three elements.


$$1+\text{R}=\left(1+\text{r}\right)\times\left(1+\text{h}\right)$$

R- the nominal return
r- the real return
h- inflation effect
We need to discuss nominal and real rates and their relationship.

## Requirement 1

We need to discuss nominal and real rates and which one is more important.

**Nominal** rate is just stated rate and **hasn't been adjusted for inflation**, therefore, it functions when inflation isn't in major effect.

On the other hand, **real rate** is rate **adjusted for inflation**, ie. actual value of the rate.

Evidently, **real rate** is more important for investors because it will **present actual rate of return** (yes, nominal rate is bigger, but real rate will always end up as actual return rate).

## Requirement 2

We need to discuss Fisher effect.

Fisher effect is actually **a representation of relation between nominal, real and inflation interest rate**, ie. how inflation changes actual used rates.

Formula representing Fisher effect is:

$$(1+\text{R}) = (1+\text{r}) \times (1+\text{h})$$

where:

$\text{R}$ = nominal rate;\
$\text{r}$ = real rate;\
$\text{h}$ = inflation rate.

These are **actual values** of each rate. Approximate rate would be simply:

$$\text{R} = \text{r} + \text{h}$$
